citation.article-title: Koserella trabulsii, a new genus and species of Enterobacteriaceae formerly known as Enteric Group 45.

p.s: Description of Koserella trabulsii sp. nov.

Koserella trabulsii (pronunciation trah-bool-see'-eye = trä-bōōl-sē'ī, derived from the surname of L. R. Trabulsi, a Brazilian bacteriologist. It honors him for his contributions to enteric bacteriology, particularly his studies on the genera Salmonella and Shigella and on diarrhea-causing Escherichia coli in Brazil)

Because of the low relatedness by DNA hybridization of Enteric Group 45 to other Enterobacteriaceae and because it does not readily fit into any of the described genera, we propose oserella as a new genus for this group of strains.
The generic name Thus, the new genus name, Koserella was coined so that an organism in the family Enterobacteriaceae could again honor Stuart Koser.
The species name koseri in Citrobacter koseri also was coined to honor Stuart Koser; however, this name is a synonym (subjective, based on DNA hybridization) of Citrobacter diversus.
Since C. koseri was proposed after C. diversus (1970 Wvrsus 1928), C. diversus is the correct name for the organism.
Acetate utilization, which is particularly useful for differentiating strains of Shigella from E. coli, is routinely done on the acetate medium of Trabulsi and Ewing (14).
Strain 3349-72 (ATCC 35313) is designated as the type strain (holotype).
There presently is only one species in the genus, so the description for the genus and the species is the same. K. trabulsii is the type species for this genus.
A complete description of K. trabulsii is given in Tables 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. K. trabulsii has the general characteristics of the family Enterobacteriaceae (Table 2).
Biochemically, K. trabulsii is closest to H. alvei.

These two organisms can be differentiated because K. trabulsii is Voges-Proskauer and glycerol negative; citrate (Simmons), cellobiose, and melibiose positive; and resistant to colistin and to the Hafnia-specific phage of Guinée and Valkenburg; (7); it also gives a very weak, delayed catalase reaction (Table 6).
All K. trabulsii strains were resistant to colistin (one intermediate) and penicillin.

All were susceptible to nalidixic acid, sulfadiazine, gentamicin, kanamycin, and chloramphenicol, but there was variable susceptibility to tetracycline, cephalothin, ampicillin, carbenicillin, and streptomycin (Table 5).
The sources of the strains and accompanying clinical information are given in Table 1.
Five of the strains were from arm and leg wounds, three were from respiratory sources, and one each was from stool, knee fluid, water, and an unknown source.
The clinical significance of this organism is unknown.
Further studies should focus on the isolation of K. trabulsii and its relationship to human disease.
